field_edited_text.value:
HiT ooy ygl

Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

U0 0L



Table 4 shows the assessed valuations by land and improvements for
the Harbor Route, the Northern Route, the sections in common, and for
the two alternative methods of completing the Inner Ring. It will be seen
that the advantage clearly lies with the Harbor Route. Assessments for
the Harbor Route are about 5% million dollars less than for the Northern
Route. Also, assessments for completing the Inner Ring with the Harbor
Route are 1% million dollars less than for completing the Inner Ring with
the Northern Route.

TABLE 4
ASSESSED VALUATION OF PROPERTIES TO BE ACQUIRED

PLanhar BRSO W e i $ 9,648,000
INOEERRER TS Ll e i s e S R $15,173,000
Bations 0 Comon . .. o 0. o v e i s b e $ 6,446,000
Completion of Inner Ring with Harbor Route............ $ 2,895,984
Completion of Inner Ring with Northern Route........... $ 4,468,490
Total Cost

The Northern Route from the western city line to its merger with the
Northeast Expressway close to the eastern city line has previously been
estimated to cost a total of $194,000,000, including right-of-way acqui-
sition. Total length is 10.2 miles.

No cost estimate has been prepared for the Harbor Route. It does
not appear, however, that its cost would be sufficiently different from the
Northern Route so that this factor should be important in arriving at a
decision between the two routes. Total length for the Harbor Route is
12.5 miles or 2.3 miles longer than the Northern Route. On the other

S5

hand, 3.0 miles of the Harbor Route represents a widening of the present
Harbor Tunnel entrance and the cost for this should be much less per
mile than for new expressway construction. New construction on the
Harbor Route is 0.7 mile less than for the Northern Route.

More of the Harbor Route is elevated than is the Northern Route
and as a general rule through highly developed areas elevated express-
ways tend to be less costly than depressed expressways. On the other
hand the Harbor Route includes one fairly extensive water crossing which
will be relatively expensive, and foundations along the edge of the harbor
may be costly.

A brief review of the Harbor Route by the Department of Public
Works indicates that there would be a number of intricate engineering
problems, the most costly being that of foundations along the Inner Har-
bor. The Department concludes that there are no engineering problems
involved that would be insurmountable. Nevertheless it would be advis-
able to have the engineering and cost aspects of the Harbor Route studied
by a qualified engineering firm. Such a study would probably be required
by the State Roads Commission before it gave approval.

If assessed valuations are a fair measure of comparative right-of-way
costs, land acquisition for the Harbor Route should be less than for the
Northern Route. On the other hand, the Harbor Route would probably
involve the payment of certain damages to the Baltimore Gas and Electric
Company, the Pennsylvania Railroad, and perhaps to the Esso Refinery.
These payments are not reflected in the assessment figures.

It could hardly be expected that either route could be built except as .
part of the National Interstate System with a 909 Federal subsidy. On
this basis either route should involve a local cost in the general range of
about $20,000,000.
